column1: #MaryLouMcDonald	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-party	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-dob	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	113	Yesterday's statement by the Minister for Health
column3: Deputy Reilly
column4: regarding the primary care centre controversy has answered none of the key questions. What we know is that the Balbriggan site belonged to a Fine Gael supporter or advocate and was selected on the Minister's watch
column5: and not that of the previous Government
column6: as had been suggested. The Minister for Health and the Taoiseach have consistently told the Dáil that there had been consultation with senior Labour Cabinet Ministers in respect of the change to criteria and the additional primary health care centres. The Minister for Social Protection
column7: Deputy Burton
column8: and the Minister for Public Expenditure and Reform
column9: Deputy Howlin
column10: all denied they were consulted. At least we now know where the senior level consultation happened
column11: as the Minister
column12: Deputy Reilly
column13: spoke to the Tánaiste about the issue. So the Tánaiste has said. When did the Tánaiste first become aware of concerns about the Minister's decision to locate two of the additional primary health care centres in his constituency? Did the former Minister of State
column14: Deputy Shortall
column15: bring her concerns to the Tánaiste before her resignation? Was he aware of those concerns when he signed off on the additional 15 health care centres? Was he aware of those concerns at the time he voted confidence in the Minister for Health
column16: Deputy Reilly? The Tánaiste made a speech about openness and reform
column17: which he is manifestly failing to deliver. I cannot understand why despite unease within his political party - two MEPs have called for the Minister
column18: Deputy Reilly
column19: to do the decent thing and step down - the Tánaiste is still standing by him. I will quote the Minister's statement from yesterday
column20: if I may.

column1: #SeanBarrett	unknown-#SeanBarrett-party	unknown-#SeanBarrett-dob	unknown-#SeanBarrett-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	114	The Deputy is nearly a minute over her time.

column1: #MaryLouMcDonald	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-party	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-dob	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	115	How is this for clarity and transparency? He stated:One and one makes two and two and two makes four but four by four makes 16 and not four and four which makes eight
column3: and so it is with this. It is a logistical logarithmic progression.Is he for real? It is clear as mud. The criteria were fixed
column4: as the Tánaiste knows
column5: and stroke politics was at the heart of the Government
column6: as the Tánaiste knows.

column1: #SeanBarrett	unknown-#SeanBarrett-party	unknown-#SeanBarrett-dob	unknown-#SeanBarrett-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	116	The Deputy should adhere to the directions of the Chair.

column1: #MaryLouMcDonald	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-party	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-dob	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	117	Answer my questions and we can see if the Tánaiste will stand by his promises for reform.

column1: #EamonGilmore	unknown-#EamonGilmore-party	unknown-#EamonGilmore-dob	unknown-#EamonGilmore-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	118	There is no secret about the fact that there were differences between the former Minister of State
column3: Deputy Shortall
column4: and the Minister for Health
column5: Deputy Reilly. At all times I supported the former Minister of State
column6: Deputy Shortall
column7: in what she was seeking to do in the Department of Health.

column1: #FinianMcGrath	unknown-#FinianMcGrath-party	unknown-#FinianMcGrath-dob	unknown-#FinianMcGrath-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	119	She does not believe that.

column1: #EamonGilmore	unknown-#EamonGilmore-party	unknown-#EamonGilmore-dob	unknown-#EamonGilmore-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	120	There were a variety of meetings held
column3: including one involving the Taoiseach
column4: me
column5: the Minister for Health and the former Minister of State
column6: Deputy Shortall. That took place prior to the summer and we put in place a working group representative of the Taoiseach and my office to address some of these issues and make progress on them.The working group has been making progress since then. My priority and that of the Government
column7: bearing in mind that we are dealing with this at a time when we have a very serious financial difficulty
column8: is to achieve reform in our health system. At the centre of that reform is a shift to primary care. There is a very good reason we want to shift to primary care; it is because people who want to access our health system have to go to their GP
column9: somewhere else to get a blood test and somewhere else to get another-----

column1: #MaryLouMcDonald	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-party	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-dob	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	121	We know all of that. It is waffle. Answer the question.

column1: #SeanBarrett	unknown-#SeanBarrett-party	unknown-#SeanBarrett-dob	unknown-#SeanBarrett-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	122	Allow the Tánaiste to continue without interruption.

column1: #EamonGilmore	unknown-#EamonGilmore-party	unknown-#EamonGilmore-dob	unknown-#EamonGilmore-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	123	It is not waffle to the parent of a sick child who has to go from Billy to Jack under our health system.

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	124	Hear
column3: hear.

column1: #EamonGilmore	unknown-#EamonGilmore-party	unknown-#EamonGilmore-dob	unknown-#EamonGilmore-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	125	Our priority as a Government is to get primary care centres provided
column3: built
column4: staffed and up and running.

column1: #MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	126	The former Minister of State
column3: Deputy Shortall does not think it is a priority.

column1: #EamonGilmore	unknown-#EamonGilmore-party	unknown-#EamonGilmore-dob	unknown-#EamonGilmore-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	127	Members of Sinn Féin were among those who constantly asked
column3: day in and day out
column4: where is the stimulus package and why is there not one. We have produced a stimulus package of €2.25 million and have taken the opportunity in that package to include the provision of primary care centres in order that we can provide in local communities a centre where somebody who is ill or who has a sick child can get the range of services provided under one roof rather than the ragged
column5: disorganised
column6: inefficient and costly system that we have at present. That is what the programme for Government states we will do and that is what we will press ahead to do. On the question of whether I was involved in terms of the criteria
column7: I was no more involved in the criteria for how primary care centres were selected in the Department of Health than I was involved in the criteria that were used in the Department of Education and Skills for the selection of schools or the criteria that were used in the Department of Transport for the selection of roads.

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	128	Hear
column3: hear.

column1: #EamonGilmore	unknown-#EamonGilmore-party	unknown-#EamonGilmore-dob	unknown-#EamonGilmore-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	129	What I was involved in
column3: and am proud to have been involved in
column4: was the production of a financial package
column5: despite all the financial difficulties this country has
column6: which provided for the building
column7: staffing and resourcing of primary care centres and our pressing ahead with that. I recently nominated Deputy Alex White to be Minister of State to take charge of that and I am confident he will deliver on it as part of the team in the Department of Health.

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	130	Hear
column3: hear.

column1: #MaryLouMcDonald	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-party	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-dob	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	131	The Tánaiste is well aware that he does not have to convince anyone in this House as to the value and necessity of primary health centres
column3: so I wish that he would dispense with what amounts to waffle when straight questions are put to him.

column1: #MaryLouMcDonald	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-party	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-dob	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	132	Let us piece it together now because the Tánaiste is not volunteering information - it has to be extracted from him.

column1: #SeanBarrett	unknown-#SeanBarrett-party	unknown-#SeanBarrett-dob	unknown-#SeanBarrett-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	133	There is a time limit of one minute on this.

column1: #MaryLouMcDonald	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-party	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-dob	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	134	The Tánaiste signed off on the additional 15 primary health care centres. When he did that he was aware of Deputy Róisín Shortall's concerns. He told us that he did not know anything about the criteria. I suggest to him that as Tánaiste he should have paid more attention and
column3: if he did not know about the criteria then I hope to God he will tell us that he has an understanding of the criteria now because none of the rest of us can make head nor tail of the incoherent bluster coming from the Minister
column4: Deputy Reilly.

column1: #SeanBarrett	unknown-#SeanBarrett-party	unknown-#SeanBarrett-dob	unknown-#SeanBarrett-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	135	Thank you
column3: Deputy.

column1: #MaryLouMcDonald	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-party	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-dob	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	136	There was a predetermined outcome to this and the criteria were fixed to achieve that. I think the Tánaiste knows that and that is the reason for his reluctance to spell out clearly and to answer clearly specific questions put to him. He signed off on the additional health centres; he did so knowing the difficulties and deep concerns Deputy Róisín Shortall had. He voted confidence in a Minister in whom I cannot see him having had any confidence. He hung Deputy Róisín Shortall out to dry and he makes no apology for doing that-----

column1: #EmmetStagg	unknown-#EmmetStagg-party	unknown-#EmmetStagg-dob	unknown-#EmmetStagg-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	137	That is rubbish.

column1: #MaryLouMcDonald	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-party	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-dob	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	138	-----and to top it all he will not even give a basic commitment
column3: if he does not understand the criteria
column4: to publish all of documentation for public scrutiny in order that the rest of us have the benefit of that information. Reform my eye.

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	139	Hear
column3: hear.

column1: #EamonGilmore	unknown-#EamonGilmore-party	unknown-#EamonGilmore-dob	unknown-#EamonGilmore-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	140	On the criteria
column3: I did not see the Deputy make any complaint about the selection of the additional primary care centre in Deputy Adams' constituency. There was no complaint about that. I did not hear any complaint from the Deputy.

column1: #MaryLouMcDonald	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-party	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-dob	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	141	We have raised the 15 centres.

column1: #EamonGilmore	unknown-#EamonGilmore-party	unknown-#EamonGilmore-dob	unknown-#EamonGilmore-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	142	That is one of the 15.

column1: #MaryLouMcDonald	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-party	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-dob	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	143	Yes. We are raising the criteria that-----

column1: #EamonGilmore	unknown-#EamonGilmore-party	unknown-#EamonGilmore-dob	unknown-#EamonGilmore-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	144	I did not hear any complaint from Deputy McDonald about what criteria were used to decide on the selection of Grangegorman in the Deputy's constituency to develop a new third level education facility
column3: which we are proud to do.

column1: #MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	145	That was a previous Government's policy.

column1: #EamonGilmore	unknown-#EamonGilmore-party	unknown-#EamonGilmore-dob	unknown-#EamonGilmore-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	146	The key issue is that the Government is pressing ahead with the reform of the health service
column3: with the provision of primary care centres which is what matters to the people and to those who want to see a better health care system. We are providing the funding for that and that was done in the stimulus package. With regard to all the allegations
column4: implications and so on that somehow there was political interference in it
column5: as I said
column6: I met today with the Minister
column7: Deputy Reilly
column8: the Secretary General of his Department
column9: the new CEO of the HSE and they told me directly that there was no ministerial involvement in the selection of any individual site.

column1: #MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	147	There was in terms of adding certain centres. The Tánaiste is being disingenuous.

column1: #EamonGilmore	unknown-#EamonGilmore-party	unknown-#EamonGilmore-dob	unknown-#EamonGilmore-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	148	I am not being disingenuous.

column1: #ShaneRoss	unknown-#ShaneRoss-party	unknown-#ShaneRoss-dob	unknown-#ShaneRoss-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	149	Perhaps I could be allowed to make the Dáil a Deputy Reilly free zone for the next few minutes to the relief perhaps of some members of the Government. That issue has tended to overshadow an equally important issue which happened three days ago and one day ago. Three days ago AIB bondholders were paid €1 billion and one day ago AIB mortgage holders were charged another 0.5% on their mortgage if they have a standard variable rate. Those mortgage holders
column3: the borrowers
column4: who are affected by this do not miss the connection and they see their money and the extra payments they are making as a direct payment going to the bondholders. The Tánaiste will be aware
column5: because it has been well publicised
column6: that those with a not unusual mortgage now of up to €300
column7: 000 will pay an extra €1
column8: 080 per annum as a result of this 0.5% rise. I do not know if he realises how many of these people simply will not be able to pay that rise - how many of these people he is going to be asking to pay more money and more taxes on the same properties in the forthcoming budget. We are now reaching a situation where middle Ireland simply cannot pay what the Government is asking it to pay. I ask the Tánaiste to please not come back to me and say this is not a Government matter. I would agree with him if he were to say this has arisen because the banks
column9: particularly AIB
column10: have been allowed to go walkabout. There is a kind of declaration of independence by AIB at the moment where it is taking its own decisions and crucifying its mortgage holders. In the meantime the Government
column11: which owns nearly 100% of the bank and has supposedly two public interest directors on its board
column12: is washing its hands of a huge problem where it can exercise a serious level of control. Is it Government policy that it contributes to and helps the increasing problem of the crippling mortgage debt we are now facing by allowing this bank
column13: which it effectively fully owns
column14: to add to the debt by putting up mortgages for those who cannot afford it?

column1: #EamonGilmore	unknown-#EamonGilmore-party	unknown-#EamonGilmore-dob	unknown-#EamonGilmore-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	150	The issue of mortgages
column3: mortgage arrears and the difficulties people have in meeting their mortgage commitments is very much a top priority for the Government. That is why
column4: as the Deputy will know
column5: we brought forward the personal insolvency legislation
column6: Report Stage of which is due to be taken in the House shortly.It is why we have put in place a range of measures to support people in mortgage difficulty and to ensure people do not lose their homes in this financial crisis. This Government
column7: unlike its predecessor
column8: has had regular engagement with the banks about a range of issues
column9: including their obligation to lend to business
column10: what they are doing about new mortgages and what they are doing to deal with the problem of mortgage arrears. We inherited the banking crisis and the decisions made by the previous Government and this is why we have worked to seek agreement at EU level on the separation of bank debt from sovereign debt and why we are insisting that that agreement be implemented in full and that the huge burden placed on the back of taxpayers as a result of the banking collapse is lifted. With regard to commercial decisions made by AIB
column11: the Deputy would be the first to criticise the Government if it sought to engage in hands on decision-making in the banks but
column12: as far as mortgage holders are concerned
column13: the Government is firmly on the side of people who are having difficulty meeting their mortgage payments and that is why we have taken the steps we have taken and will continue to do so.

column1: #ShaneRoss	unknown-#ShaneRoss-party	unknown-#ShaneRoss-dob	unknown-#ShaneRoss-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	151	I thank the Tánaiste for his reply but I would like to correct him. I would be the first to say that the Government should intervene on a day-to-day basis on decisions of this sort. The Government owns it and it has two directors on the bank's board. I do not know what they are there for if they are not there to have an input into policy decisions. AIB has a disgraceful record as regards mortgages and it has brought the country to its knees. The people who were there then are still there now. Appointments of the old cronies are still being made to the board and the old people are resurfacing. The Government should ring up the bank to say: "It is not Government policy. We do not want a 0.5% increase in mortgage interests rates for these people and we forbid you to do it." This increase is obviously part of Government policy. It is rather like a tax because the Government is asking the people who are being charged an additional 0.5% to support a State asset which is losing money. It is equivalent to a tax and I suggest the Tánaiste should intervene and say there will be no more interest rate rises at this stage by giving instructions to the directors who are there at his beck and call. I do not know what they do. What proportion of the money AIB will take in through this increase will go to the bank? Is the Tánaiste aware that a large number of the bank's mortgages have been securitised and sold off in bundles to other institutions outside this jurisdiction? Much of this money will not even go to the AIB or the Exchequer. It will go outside the country because the mortgages have been securitised. I do not expect the Tánaiste to give a specific answer to that now but I would like to know what proportion of the money will go to AIB.

column1: #EamonGilmore	unknown-#EamonGilmore-party	unknown-#EamonGilmore-dob	unknown-#EamonGilmore-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	152	I do not propose to take advice from the Deputy about how the banks should be run because I recall the advice he gave the previous Government when he said it should make Sean FitzPatrick the governor of the Bank of Ireland.

column1: #FinianMcGrath	unknown-#FinianMcGrath-party	unknown-#FinianMcGrath-dob	unknown-#FinianMcGrath-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	153	Here we go again. That is the Taoiseach's line.

column1: #MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	154	That is an old one.

column1: #EamonGilmore	unknown-#EamonGilmore-party	unknown-#EamonGilmore-dob	unknown-#EamonGilmore-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	155	Deputy Ross does not have a particularly good track record on this. I will also not come into the House to defend the practices of banks
column3: now or in the past. What the Government is doing in regard to our banking system is to ensure
column4: first
column5: we have a banking system that is fit for purpose for our economy. It is a work in progress and there are a number of dimensions to it
column6: one of which is resolving the issue of the separation of the debts associated with banks and the State. This work is a priority for the Government. Second
column7: we want to ensure our banks serve our economy and our people
column8: and this is why we have a continuing and regular dialogue with them about that. Third
column9: we want to ensure the homes of people who are paying their mortgage are not at risk
column10: and that is why we are putting in place the personal insolvency legislation
column11: the support and advice system and a range of housing supports through the Department of the Environment
column12: Community and Local Government. The interest of mortgage holders and their needs is very much at the front of the approach the Government is taking with our banks. It is a work in progress.

column1: #FinianMcGrath	unknown-#FinianMcGrath-party	unknown-#FinianMcGrath-dob	unknown-#FinianMcGrath-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	156	Is there a Labour Party member on the bank's board?

column1: #ShaneRoss	unknown-#ShaneRoss-party	unknown-#ShaneRoss-dob	unknown-#ShaneRoss-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	157	Dick Spring.

column1: #EamonGilmore	unknown-#EamonGilmore-party	unknown-#EamonGilmore-dob	unknown-#EamonGilmore-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	158	It is difficult work but it is work in which we will succeed.

column1: #MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	159	The Tánaiste is becoming more like the Taoiseach every day as he manages to avoid answering questions.

column1: #EamonGilmore	unknown-#EamonGilmore-party	unknown-#EamonGilmore-dob	unknown-#EamonGilmore-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	160	I am answering them but the Deputy does not like the answers.

column1: #EamonGilmore	unknown-#EamonGilmore-party	unknown-#EamonGilmore-dob	unknown-#EamonGilmore-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	161	It is proposed to take No. 5
column3: Europol Bill 2012 - Order for Second Stage and Second Stage. It is proposed
column4: notwithstanding anything in Standing Orders
column5: that in regard to the Assaults on Emergency Workers Bill 2012
column6: the Second Stage of which shall be considered tomorrow
column7: the following arrangements shall apply: the opening speech of the main spokespersons for Fianna Fáil
column8: Sinn Féin
column9: the Technical Group and a Minister or Minister of State
column10: who shall be called upon in that order and who may share their time
column11: shall not exceed 15 minutes in each case; the speech of each other Member called upon shall not exceed 15 minutes and such Members may share time; a Minister or Minister of State
column12: who may speak twice
column13: shall be called upon not later than 1 p.m. to make a speech which shall not exceed 15 minutes; and the main spokesperson for Fianna Fáil shall be called upon to make a speech in reply which shall not exceed 15 minutes.

column1: #SeanBarrett	unknown-#SeanBarrett-party	unknown-#SeanBarrett-dob	unknown-#SeanBarrett-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	162	There is one proposal to put the House. Is the proposal for dealing with the Assaults on Emergency Workers Bill 2012 tomorrow agreed to? Agreed.

column1: #MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	163	I must remark on this week's lack of business. I have asked the Taoiseach on a number of occasions if he could schedule an urgent debate on the Irish Fiscal Advisory Council report
column3: which is almost four weeks old. It goes to the heart of some of the significant economic challenges we face and it voices significant concerns. I would have thought we could have had the debate yesterday or today
column4: so important is that report as an independent
column5: objective assessment of where we are fiscally and so on. I refer to forthcoming legislation relating to children. People are worried about what they are reading and about the leaks concerning significant reductions in child benefit payments down to €100 with a scheme of top-ups. Will the Tánaiste confirm when the Children First Bill is coming on stream? Will he confirm whether there will be reductions in child benefit in the forthcoming budget?

column1: #SeanBarrett	unknown-#SeanBarrett-party	unknown-#SeanBarrett-dob	unknown-#SeanBarrett-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	164	That is not in order on the Order of Business.

column1: #EamonGilmore	unknown-#EamonGilmore-party	unknown-#EamonGilmore-dob	unknown-#EamonGilmore-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	165	With regard to the Irish Fiscal Advisory Council report
column3: the Fiscal Responsibility Bill 2012 will be in the House next week and that will give Members an opportunity to debate the report and it is also intended to hold a debate reasonably soon on the economic situation- it is a matter for the Whips to agree the timing of it - and this can obviously include the report.

column1: #MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	166	The Taoiseach undertook that there would be a debate specifically on the Irish Fiscal Advisory Council report
column3: not the Bill. There are concerns in that report and issues that need airing and articulation. The goalposts are changing.

column1: #EamonGilmore	unknown-#EamonGilmore-party	unknown-#EamonGilmore-dob	unknown-#EamonGilmore-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	167	There is quite a degree of latitude when Second Stage of a Bill is debated. The Fiscal Responsibility Bill will be in the House next week. It would be extraordinary if that debate did not include reference and discussion of the Irish Fiscal Advisory Council report but
column3: in any event
column4: it is our intention that there will be a wider debate on the economy
column5: which will obviously include the report.The Deputy asked me about child benefit-----

column1: #SeanBarrett	unknown-#SeanBarrett-party	unknown-#SeanBarrett-dob	unknown-#SeanBarrett-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	168	We are on the Order of Business and we do not deal with such matters.

column1: #EamonGilmore	unknown-#EamonGilmore-party	unknown-#EamonGilmore-dob	unknown-#EamonGilmore-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	169	It is amazing what a period in opposition will do for one's amnesia.

column1: #FinianMcGrath	unknown-#FinianMcGrath-party	unknown-#FinianMcGrath-dob	unknown-#FinianMcGrath-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	170	There are many comedians in the House today.

column1: #NiallCollins	unknown-#NiallCollins-party	unknown-#NiallCollins-dob	unknown-#NiallCollins-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	171	Deputy Gilmore has forgotten about his past.

column1: #EamonGilmore	unknown-#EamonGilmore-party	unknown-#EamonGilmore-dob	unknown-#EamonGilmore-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	172	The issue of child benefit and how it might be structured goes back to when Mary Hanafin was Minister
column3: followed by Deputy Ó Cuív.

column1: #MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	173	I am referring to the recent report.

column2: President of the European Parliament	174	The issue of child benefit will be considered in the context of the budget. The children first Bill will be taken this session.

column1: #MaryLouMcDonald	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-party	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-dob	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	175	I refer to promised legislation on upward only rent review. The matter is under review and there are some complications. The rental arrangements people have with the State and State agencies must be addressed. Regarding the Keane report
column3: the Tánaiste spoke of his concern for people in mortgage distress. What is coming forward from the recommendations by way of legislation? I refer to the Dolphin report
column4: which has not yet been published
column5: on the location of the children's hospital. There is heightened anxiety about where it might be located given the jiggery-pokery we saw on primary health care centres. It is essential that any decision on this development is absolutely transparent. When will the report be published and when will the Government take a decision on the location
column6: given the need for transparency?

column2: President of the European Parliament	176	The Minister for Finance addressed upward only rent reviews in his Budget Statement last December. He set out the position and referred to the advice received from the Attorney General.

column2: President of the European Parliament	177	Does that mean nothing is happening?

column2: President of the European Parliament	179	I want an answer
column3: not a debate.

column2: President of the European Parliament	180	He set out the position. There is a constitutional issue related to it
column3: which the Minister for Finance addressed. The Government accepted the recommendations of the Keane report and we had a debate in the House in which we set out
column4: in great detail
column5: the action taken by the Government on foot of the report. The key item of legislation arising from the report is the Personal Insolvency Bill. The Bill has passed Committee Stage and is due to come into the House for Report Stage. The Dolphin report on the children's hospital is with the Minister for Health and when he is in a position to bring it to Government
column6: he will do so. When the Government has considered the matter
column7: an announcement will be made.

column2: President of the European Parliament	185	A number of local contractors and a subcontractor are working on the road and have not been paid by the main contractor. This is leading to major difficulties.

This is a major issue because people are expending money and they want to put bread on the table for their families. They cannot do so because they are not being paid by the big operators.

column2: President of the European Parliament	195	In view of recent concerns about credit reporting
column3: when is it expected to bring the credit reporting Bill into the House
column4: with a view to addressing the issues that have become apparent? That would cover some of the banking procedures
column5: including lending procedures. Similarly
column6: in respect of company law
column7: it appears from casual observation that company law is not being observed in the letter and the spirit of the law in numerous instances over the past four or five years. Two items of company legislation are proposed
column8: the companies Bill and a consolidation Bill. Is it possible to bring these legislative measures before the House earlier than had been anticipated
column9: with a view to addressing ongoing issues?

column1: #EamonGilmore	unknown-#EamonGilmore-party	unknown-#EamonGilmore-dob	unknown-#EamonGilmore-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	196	The companies legislation is due this session and the credit reporting Bill was published last Friday. It is a matter of scheduling with the Whips when it is brought before the House. I expect it to be in the House shortly.

column1: #SeanOFearghaillFF	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-party	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-dob	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	197	What is the position in respect of convening the constitutional convention? We raised the matter on the Order of Business last week and we understood we would be given an advice note on the matter. That has not happened. The challenge is to select the 66 members of the public
column3: which is a daunting task. I also asked for consultation with Opposition parties in respect of the independent chair but there has been no update on this point. Does it look rather unlikely that the pet project of the Government will be launched this side of the budget?

column1: #EamonGilmore	unknown-#EamonGilmore-party	unknown-#EamonGilmore-dob	unknown-#EamonGilmore-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	198	It is intended to have the constitutional convention launched this side of the budget. We are making arrangements to have it announced and launched. With regard to consultation on its composition
column3: there have already been discussions with Opposition parties. We do not have any difficulty with further discussion on it. We would like to see it done in a manner to which we can subscribe rather than in a partisan way. I have no difficulty with further discussion with Opposition parties.

column2: President of the European Parliament	201	I wish to advise the House of the following matters in respect of which notice has been given under Standing Order 27A and the name of the Member in each case: (1) Deputies Ann Phelan and Thomas Pringle - the need to make provision for self-employed workers who are seeking to claim for social welfare; (2) Deputy Robert Troy - the vacant position of director of the HSE’s national office for suicide prevention; (3) Deputy Derek Keating - the problems in collecting social welfare payments at Lucan village
column3: Dublin; (4) Deputy Martin Heydon - the need to include a new primary school at Crookstown
column4: Ballitore
column5: Athy
column6: County Kildare on the Department of Education's five year building programme; (5) Deputy Jonathan O'Brien - the loss of jobs at the Merck Sharpe Dohme pharmacy plant
column7: Innishannon
column8: County Cork; (6) Deputy John O'Mahony - the need to address the waiting times for applications for social protection and in particular carer’s allowance; (7) Deputy Aengus Ó Snodaigh - the need to open a new purpose built 70 bed public nursing home in Inchicore
column9: Dublin; (8) Deputy Michael Conaghan - the threat posed by escalating gang-related violence; (9) Deputy John Deasy - the loss of 55 jobs at KEL-Tech Engineering
column10: Waterford; (10) Deputy Dessie Ellis - the problems for regular taxi drivers arising from the proposed ending of the transferability of licences from January 2013; (11) Deputy Brendan Smith - the continued imprisonment of Irish trained doctors in Bahrain; (12) Deputy Pádraig Mac Lochlainn - the possible re-opening of the pilot training college in Waterford by a different company; (13) Deputy Mick Wallace - the raid by the Revenue's customs service on two illegal diesel laundries and the effect this illegal activity has on jobs; (14) Deputy Mattie McGrath - the need to allow some leniency and discretion when considering applications for the back to education allowance and the progression through education condition; (15) Deputy Joan Collins - the need to discuss the principle of the universal payment of child benefit; (16) Deputy Richard Boyd Barrett - the position of teachers employed in VECs in view of new Teaching Council regulations; (17) Deputy Charlie McConalogue - the need to address Ireland's position in the most recent world university rankings; and (18) Deputy Patrick O'Donovan - the need for banks
column11: credit card companies and other credit institutions to provide information to the authorities to combat the illegal importation of prescription drugs. The matters raised by Deputies Robert Troy; John Deasy; Michael Conaghan; and Ann Phelan and Thomas Pringle have been selected for discussion.

column1: #AlanShatter	unknown-#AlanShatter-party	unknown-#AlanShatter-dob	unknown-#AlanShatter-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	202	I move: "That Second Stage be taken now."

column1: #AlanShatter	unknown-#AlanShatter-party	unknown-#AlanShatter-dob	unknown-#AlanShatter-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	203	I move: "That the Bill be now read a Second Time." I am pleased to present this Bill to the House which will enable Ireland to implement an EU Council decision establishing the European Police Office
column3: or Europol. While Europol has existed since 1995
column4: it did so on the basis of an EU convention. That convention has been subject to a number of amendments introduced through subsequent protocols. However
column5: such legal instruments are subject to lengthy ratification procedures by member states and therefore it was agreed to replace those instruments with a Council decision which will ease any future amendments. In 2008
column6: the Houses of the Oireachtas approved the adoption by the State of the Council decision which ultimately entered into force in 2010. The convention and protocols
column7: to which I have referred
column8: were given force of law in the State by way of the Europol Act 1997
column9: as amended. Section 2(1) of that Act states that the convention and the protocols "shall have the force of law in the State and judicial notice shall be taken of them". Such wording
column10: which is usual for the implementation of international agreements such as conventions
column11: effectively precludes the need to legislate for each and every article of the instrument. In effect
column12: the 1997 Act
column13: as amended
column14: is relatively minimalist. However
column15: a Council decision must be implemented in a manner whereby each and every aspect of the instrument which has domestic effect must be provided for in legislation. For that reason
column16: this Bill is significantly more detailed than the existing Europol Act. None the less
column17: this Act will
column18: in effect
column19: maintain the status quo. Although the Council decision does introduce a small number of changes to Europol
column20: to which I will refer shortly
column21: it replicates
column22: to a very large extent
column23: the provisions of the convention and the protocols thereto. Turning to Europol itself
column24: I will briefly mention one change which the Council decision introduced. Under the convention
column25: Europol had the status of an intergovernmental organisation funded by contributions from member states. However
column26: establishing Europol under a Council decision gives it the status of an agency of the European Union. As an agency in the area of police and judicial co-operation in criminal matters
column27: Europol joins CEPOL
column28: the European Police College
column29: and Eurojust
column30: the EU's judicial co-operation unit. Establishing Europol as an entity of the EU ensures it is funded from the general budget of the European Union and also enhances the role of the European Parliament in the control of Europol. The objective of Europol
column32: is to improve the effectiveness and co-operation of the law enforcement authorities of member states in preventing and combating organised crime
column33: terrorism and other forms of serious crime affecting two or more member states. This is another difference between the Council decision and the convention and probably the most significant change from an operational point of view. The Council decision extends the mandate of Europol from that under the convention. Organised crime was originally the sole focus of Europol's activities. The Council decision removes the requirement that an organised criminal structure must be involved before Europol can act. It will be sufficient for the crime concerned to involve a serious offence
column34: as listed in the annex to the Council decision. These serious offences include the main transnational crimes such as drug trafficking
column38: counterfeiting or arms smuggling. They also include other more serious crimes such as murder
column39: organised robbery and kidnapping. Europol's role in supporting and strengthening action by the member states in combating such crime is clearly set out in Article 3 of the Council decision. It is the reality that no member state
column42: can avoid the impact of international crime. The very nature of this crime requires the co-operation of several states to ensure an effective response. Europol self-describes its role as that of making Europe safer and it does so by providing the necessary co-ordination of and support for national law enforcement authorities. The support and assistance which Europol can offer to any investigation can be broadly categorised as information management and
column44: semi-operational tasks. The latter tasks include the option for Europol to participate in joint investigation teams. Primarily
column46: Europol co-ordinates and supports Europe-wide operations investigating serious criminal activity. All arrests and policing functions are carried out by the competent law enforcement authority in the member state in question. Europol assists member states in combating crime on a daily basis and
column48: this assistance is achieved through the secure intelligence exchange between the Irish Europol national unit based in Garda headquarters and the Irish liaison bureau located in Europol headquarters in The Hague. Europol has established a number of crime priority areas which are assigned a team of analysts and which Ireland contributes to daily. The information gathered has assisted in identifying links between international organised crime groups operating in Ireland and in other jurisdictions. In terms of operations
column49: in 2011 Ireland assisted Europol in the provision of intelligence and information about a mobile organised crime gang which was involved in the organised thefts of rhino horn throughout continental Europe. That work continues with ongoing intelligence exchange between Ireland and other member states in relation to this gang who are also involved in the commission of crimes including burglaries
column52: money laundering and drug trafficking. Europol has also assisted Ireland in the area of illegal immigration. Ireland has taken part in operational meetings involving the exchange of information and intelligence concerning an organised crime gang operating in France that assists illegal immigration to Ireland. This operation
column54: has resulted in a number of arrests in France. More recently
column55: An Garda Síochána took part in a joint operation with the PSNI targeting prostitution on the island of Ireland. Europol again assisted this operation through the deployment of analysts who worked alongside the Gardaí and PSNI personnel. Europol continues to be of major assistance in combating and preventing crime. It is an essential means of exchanging and analysing information and intelligence and ensuring European law enforcement agencies are alerted to new threats. Turning now to the Bill
column56: I would like to highlight some of its main provisions. Section 2 confirms that the competent authorities for the purpose of the Act and the Council decision are the Commissioner of the Garda Síochána or
column57: in relation to a revenue offence
column58: the Revenue Commissioners. Competent authorities are defined in article 3 of the Council decision as "all public bodies existing in the member states which are responsible under national law for preventing and combating criminal offences". Sections 4 and 5 provide for the Europol national unit
column59: including the functions of that unit. Those functions are set out in Article 8 of the Council decision and include liaising with Europol and the competent authorities of other member states
column60: responding to requests for information and intelligence and performing such other tasks as are required by the Council decision. The provision allows the national unit to refuse a request for information where to provide such information would prejudice the security or other essential interests of the State
column61: prejudice a criminal investigation or criminal proceedings in the State
column62: or jeopardise the safety of a person or persons. Section 5 also clarifies that the national unit may access the Europol information system as permitted under the Council decision. Section 6 provides for the role and functions of liaison officers. This provision replicates the existing section 4 of the Europol Act 1997. Under this provision
column63: a liaison officer may be sent from the national unit to Europol to serve in the Irish liaison bureau. A liaison officer may not necessarily be a member of the Garda Síochána and could
column65: be an officer of the Revenue Commissioners. Currently
column66: Ireland has two liaison officers based in Europol
column67: one from An Garda Síochána and one who is an officer of the Revenue Commissioners. These officers provide co-ordination between Europol and the national unit in the transmission of information and otherwise co-operate with Europol in accordance with the Council decision. Section 7 gives effect to Article 7 of the Council decision which permits Europol to request member states to initiate criminal investigations. A request must be made to the national unit which will transmit the request to the competent authority of the State
column68: that is the Garda Síochána or the Revenue Commissioners. The competent authority will consider and decide whether to comply with the request. The national unit will notify Europol of the decision as to whether to conduct the investigation. Where it is decided to refuse the request
column69: the national unit will inform Europol of the reasons for refusing
column70: unless to do so would harm essential national security interests
column71: prejudice an ongoing criminal investigation or proceedings or would jeopardise the safety of any person or persons. This provision
column72: which was initially introduced into the convention in 2002
column73: responds to previous difficulties with regard to member states acting upon information provided by Europol. However
column74: it must be emphasised that An Garda Síochána
column75: the Revenue Commissioners and the law enforcement authorities in other member states have absolute discretion in the prioritisation and deployment of resources. Section 8 provides for the transmission of data to the Europol information system. This system is used to store personal information about people who are suspected or convicted of having committed a crime for which Europol has competence or where there are reasonable grounds to believe that they will commit such an offence. Subsections (2) and (3) set out the types of data which may be input and which are also set out in the Council decision. As can be expected
column76: this data includes information concerning a person's identity
column79: address and driving licence or passport information. Also included is the possibility of providing DNA data which
column80: owing to the lack of the appropriate technology
column81: was not in the previous Europol instruments. Now
column83: the use and sharing of DNA information is a key element of criminal justice systems across Europe. However
column84: it should be pointed out that neither the Council decision nor the Bill requires the obtaining of such DNA data and it will only be provided where it is available. Section 9 concerns the transmission of data to Europol for purposes other than under section 8
column86: for input in the Europol information system
column88: Europol may include information in a system known as analysis work files. This system offers broader information than the Europol information system although with much more limited access. These files allow Europol to provide operational analysis with the aim of assisting criminal investigations. Information may also be used by Europol and transmitted to third states or other entities. However
column89: the prior consent of the national unit is required before any onward transmission of the data by another party may take place. Sections 10 to 14 concern the use of
column90: access to and protection of personal data to which the Bill applies. On a general point
column91: it must be noted that data under the legislation is subject to the provisions and protections of the Data Protection Acts. There is a very strong data protection regime in place in Europol. It is generally highly regarded
column92: most recently in a 2012 report following an evaluation of the implementation of the Council decision and of Europol's activities. While not making any changes to Europol's systems of data protection
column93: the Council decision does establish a data protection officer at Europol. Although such an officer has always been a part of Europol
column94: the Council decision makes it a formal and independent role. The functions of the data protection officer are set out in article 28 of the Council decision and include ensuring compliance with the provisions of the Council decision concerning the processing of personal data. Where there are concerns concerning compliance
column95: the data protection officer may raise it directly with the director of Europol. In addition to these safeguards
column98: giving effect in the main to articles 12 and 13 of the Council decision. These functions are the responsibility of the inputting party. Data must be deleted
column100: where it relates to a case where proceedings are definitively dropped or a person is acquitted. This section also creates an obligation on the national unit or liaison officer
column102: to notify an inputting party of their belief that data input by that party is incorrect or should be supplemented. Section 11 confirms that the national unit or liaison officers may access and receive data from the Europol information system for the purpose of preventing and combating those crimes which fall within the competence of Europol. There is also provision for limited access to the system by the competent authorities who may directly query it
column103: although any data that is located can only be obtained via the national unit. Section 12 concerns the use of data in the State and confirms that data obtained from any of Europol's processing files shall only be used to prevent and combat crimes in respect of which Europol is competent and to prevent and combat other serious crimes. The State is also obliged to abide by any restrictions placed on the use of data. Section 13 provides for access by individuals to personal data. This provision allows persons to request information as to whether data relating to him or her has been processed by Europol and to have such information communicated to him or her. Grounds for objecting to a disclosure of data are set out under subsection (6) which permits the State to object where it considers that providing the information would likely prejudice the sovereignty
column104: security or other essential interests of the State
column105: prejudice a criminal investigation or criminal proceeding in the State or would prejudice the rights and freedoms of any person. This section also replicates
column107: section 6 of the Europol Act 1997. Section 14 designates the Data Protection Commissioner as the national supervisory body for the purpose of the Bill and the Council decision. This provision gives effect to article 33 of the Council decision and replicates section 7 of the Europol Act 1997. The national supervisory body is responsible for monitoring the management and processing of personal data by the State in the context of its relationship with Europol. This section also confirms the authority of the Data Protection Commissioner to access data provided to the Europol information system and the requirement on the Data Protection Commissioner to inform the joint supervisory body of any action taken with respect to the Europol information system. The joint supervisory body is an independent body with the task of ensuring compliance by Europol with data protection principles. The body is made up of representatives of national data protection authorities
column108: including the Irish Data Protection Commissioner. It should be further noted that
column110: the Official Secrets Act 1963 applies to facts or information which come to the knowledge of any director
column112: employee or other person connected with Europol. This provision replicates section 9 of the Europol Act 1997. Section 17 confirms the validity of acts done in accordance with the Europol Act 1997 or the Council decision prior to the passing of this Bill. The Council decision establishing Europol applies from 1 January 2010. As has been mentioned
column113: it repealed and replaced the Europol convention and its protocols. However
column114: existing Irish law gave force of law to the convention and its protocols and it is arguable that as these instruments have now been repealed the status of the Europol national unit and its powers as set out in the existing legislation are unclear. Following legal advice
column115: this transitional provision seeks to put beyond doubt the status of the national unit by providing that the acts done by the national unit and liaison officers during the intervening period are valid. The Attorney General has indicated that "there is no difficulty in providing retrospective validation of anything done by the existing national unit". The remaining provisions are of a standard or technical nature. Before concluding
column116: I wish to draw the attention of the House to the future of Europol. It has been given responsibility for the establishment of the European cybercrime centre which will place it at the forefront in the continuing fight against high tech organised crime. Ireland
column117: through the Garda Síochána computer crime investigation unit and the staff at the liaison bureau in The Hague
column118: will continue to offer advice and expertise to assist the cybercrime centre when it becomes operational. In 2013
column119: Europol will publish the serious organised crime threat assessment or SOCTA. On the basis of this document
column120: the Council of the European Union will determine its priorities and recommendations for the fight against organised crime in Europe. Also in 2013
column121: Ireland will take up the chairmanship of the Europol management board
column122: which is Europol's governing board. This board gives strategic guidance and oversees the implementation of Europol's tasks. Each year
column123: the management board adopts Europol's final budget
column124: the work programme of future activities and a general report on activities carried out during the previous year. These will be submitted to the Council for endorsement and to the European Parliament for information. I will also comment on the future regulation of Europol. Article 88 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union provides for a new legal regime for Europol
column125: stipulating that Europol shall be governed by a regulation or regulations. While the main policy objective of the new regulation will be to align Europol's legal base with that treaty
column128: also seek to address any recommendations arising from the recent evaluation of Europol's activities. The implementation of the Council decision is an important step in ensuring that Europol can adapt in a flexible manner without the need for complicated ratification processes by member states. The extension of its mandate reflects the very significant contribution which Europol has made to combating serious and organised crime across borders. Since its establishment in 1995
column129: Europol has evolved to become an essential tool for national law enforcement agencies in their efforts to combat this form of crime. Such crime is increasingly cross border and without the overall strategic analysis of an agency such as Europol
column130: combating that crime would be a more difficult task. I thank Members for their attention and I look forward to hearing their contributions to the debate on this important Bill

column2: President of the European Parliament	204	Fianna Fáil supports this Bill. It will help to empower the pan-European policing organisation
column3: Europol
column4: to combat international criminal gangs. The creation of pan-European freedom of movement in goods and capital has inevitably generated transcontinental criminal movements. The Bill equips Europol to help member state police forces to work together in tackling gangs involved in serious criminality across the EU and its borders. The Bill

column6: is technical in nature. It is a measure to give regard to the change in status of Europol. Europol is the European law enforcement agency and the Council decision necessitating the Bill means it will come under the functions and institutions of the European Union. Prior to this
column7: Europol was a separate international institution that assisted EU member states in fighting serious international crime
column8: including terrorism
column9: international drug trafficking
column10: money laundering
column11: fraud
column12: counterfeiting
column13: human trafficking and cyber-crime

column15: after a bloody September

column17: affecting numerous member states. Clearly

column20: analyses intelligence and co-ordinates cross-jurisdictional operations. This Bill places Europol under the clear remit of the EU and subjects it to financial and administrative scrutiny and accountability

column23: with 698 staff employed at its headquarters in The Hague
column24: including 129 liaison officers. As a result of this Bill

column28: with a number of current affairs programmes on it as recently as this week. Unfortunately

There are well-documented instances of adults and elderly people being victims of cyber-bullying. I note there is legislation on the B list of the Government legislation programme
column32: but that is concerned with cyber attacks on IT systems and does not address bullying. We must come back to this issue. Another operation
column34: led to the closing down of a counterfeit operation in Borris-in-Ossory

A recent report by the RAND Corporation think tank in the United States highlighted tensions between member states trying to support the operations while maintaining the primacy of the member states. The report identified four specific areas that needed further analysis. The first was evaluating whether and how the requirement contained in Article 8.4 for member states to share information with Europol is implemented. The second was understanding the scope for further involvement by Europol in joint investigation teams. The third issue was the collecting of information about the impact of the staff regulations on Europol's operations

Almost every Bill coming through the House that involves people's personal details are being collected and kept must contain a reference to the Data Protection Commissioner. From time to time we hear of people's personal data falling into the wrong hands for whatever reason. We must give serious consideration to the resourcing of the Office of the Data Protection Commissioner because the workload which is coming through these Houses is directly impacting on that office and its role and responsibilities. We recognise the constraints under the recruitment embargo but we must channel some staff to give the Data Protection Commissioner more resources to deal with the legislation that is being introduced. Yesterday we agreed in the Joint Committee on Justice
column39: Defence and Equality to ask the Garda Commissioner to attend to address the issues that are afflicting Dublin and the wider community as a result of gangland criminality
column41: theft and burglary. Should the Garda Commissioner take up our invitation
