column1: #MichaelNoonan	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-party	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-dob	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	323	There is a wealth of analysis on the impact of property taxes on an economy as a whole. Normally
column3: it is positive rather than negative. An increase in income tax
column4: for example
column5: would be far more negative. A property tax is applied on a fixed basis in that everybody who owns property pays unless he is subject to an exemption
column6: for example. The data are available. The impact on individuals will be assessed in the preparation for the budget.

column1: #MichaelNoonan	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-party	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-dob	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	324	The Deputy refers to companies based in Shannon. There is no preferential tax rate for companies operating out of the Shannon region. All companies based in Ireland are subject to the same rate of tax on their trading income
column3: which is 12.5%. The 10% corporation tax regime for companies based in Shannon Airport ceased in 2005. I am aware of recent media reports that refer to the ways that some companies structure their international tax affairs to minimise their tax costs
column4: and the fact that some of these reports make reference to Irish companies being part of these structures. I understand some of these reports have suggested that some companies in multinational groups pay Irish corporation tax at rates that are significantly lower than 12.5%. Such companies are not paying a low rate of Irish tax; all companies in Ireland pay at the standard rate of 12.5% on their profits which are generated in Ireland. The reports concerned appear to have incorrectly attributed to Ireland profits that represent the return due to assets in other jurisdictions
column5: which assets are owned by group companies that are not resident in Ireland. It is incorrect to relate the 12.5% corporation tax rate to both the profits of the Irish-resident group companies and the profits of foreign-resident group companies
column6: which are not profits chargeable to Irish corporation tax. By mixing up the Irish profits and the foreign profits of multinational groups like this
column7: these reports can suggest an average tax rate for the companies concerned that is lower than 12.5%
column8: and make an incorrect inference that the full Irish profits are not being charged. Multinational groups with subsidiaries in other countries in addition to Ireland incur other bona fide expenditure. Licence payments
column9: which are paid to group companies in foreign jurisdictions for the use of intellectual property rights
column10: are properly deductible in computing Irish profits. If these licence payments are untaxed in the foreign jurisdiction
column11: it will reduce the average rate of tax for the total profits of the Irish and the foreign-resident subsidiaries when these are taken together. Nevertheless
column12: the full Irish measure of profits is being taxed and the rate of tax actually paid on the profits of the Irish-resident subsidiaries is 12.5%. The ability of entities to lower their effective rate of tax using international structures reflects the global context in which Ireland and indeed all countries operate. The tax system in Ireland has a positive international reputation based on transparency and the fact that it is applied equally and openly to all corporate taxpayers. That Ireland has an extensive tax treaty network confirms our international standing. The January 2011

column1: Global Forum peer review report on Ireland's legal and regulatory framework for transparency and exchange of information found Ireland has an effective system for the exchange of information in tax matters and is fully compliant with OECD standards.
Additional information not given on the floor of the House
Our job in government is to bring investment and jobs to Ireland and we have used the tax code and
column2: in particular
column3: our competitive corporation tax system to do so for over 50 years. What companies do outside of Ireland is beyond the scope of the Irish tax system. We cannot conclusively determine the effective rate of tax paid under international tax structures by reference to taxation in Ireland alone but we continue to work with international bodies to ensure fair play. Ireland is bound by the same rules on state aid
column4: the code of conduct on business taxation
column5: and rulings of the European Court of Justice as all EU member states. Ireland does not support harmful tax competition. Ireland continues to participate fully in the EU code of conduct group
column6: which addresses harmful tax competition
column7: and in the OECD forum on harmful tax practices.

column2: President of the European Parliament	325	When some of us on this side of the House rail against the austerity the Minister is imposing on working people and the vulnerable
column3: he always asks us for an alternative
column4: implying there is none. I almost felt sorry for him earlier when he said we are never helpful. Let me be helpful by offering him some alternatives. The case of just one company based in Shannon
column5: one of the most profitable companies operating in the State
column6: points to the alternative. GE Capital Aviation Funding
column7: based in Shannon
column8: earned €606 million in profit last year and paid but €379
column9: 000 in tax. This represents an effective tax rate of 0.5%. If the company had paid at a rate of 12.5%
column10: it would have paid €95 million in tax. This would cover almost all the savage cuts that the Minister for Health
column11: Deputy James Reilly
column12: imposed over recent weeks on home help and mental health services
column13: and which he attempted to impose on the disabled. I refer to just one company that is paying tax at such a negligible level
column14: and which is not even paying at the standard corporation tax rate of 12.5%. How much more revenue will be available if we force the corporations in the State to pay at a rate of 12.5%
column15: which they are not paying at present? Last week
column16: I asked the Minister a parliamentary question on the effective tax rate being paid by companies in the State but I did not receive a proper answer. I was told the amount was difficult to calculate. Dr. Jim Stewart of the school of business studies in Trinity College estimates that companies in Ireland are paying corporation tax on profits at a rate of between 4% and 7%. Therefore
column17: will the Minister ensure that all companies pay at the effective rate of 12.5%? If they did so
column18: it would generate
column19: by any estimate
column20: several billion euro in extra revenue for the State
column21: thereby eliminating the need to impose brutal
column22: austere cuts on low and middle-income earners
column23: families on social welfare and the vulnerable.

column1: #MichaelNoonan	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-party	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-dob	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	326	I cannot comment on the tax affairs of an individual or individual company. Their relationships with the Revenue Commissioners are confidential and I do not have access to the relevant information. I cannot comment on individual cases raised by Deputy Boyd Barrett but can assure him that the low rate of taxation that applied to the Shannon Airport region ended in 2005. As with everywhere else
column3: the region's companies' profits are taxable at a rate of 12.5%. That is the tax rate. While companies may be treated differently abroad
column4: they pay at a rate of 12.5% on profits in Ireland.

column1: #RichardBoydBarrett	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-party	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-dob	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	327	Either the Minister is not examining the issue seriously or he is being disingenuous. I cited an example of one of the country's most profitable companies paying a corporation tax rate of 0.5%. It was well publicised. Is it not of concern that the tax forgone to the State is approximately €90 million at a time when Ministers are considering imposing further brutal attacks on people in the coming budget? Another set of figures show that total profits in Ireland amounted to €51 billion in 2008
column3: but that the effective tax rate across all corporations was 10%. If the Government increased that rate to 12.5%
column4: an extra €1.25 billion would accrue to the State. Is this not a problem that the Minister should examine? Does it not concern him that multinational corporations are getting away with murder and not even paying the derisory 12.5% corporate tax rate at a time when cruel austerity is being imposed on people who cannot afford it?

column1: #MichaelKitt	unknown-#MichaelKitt-party	unknown-#MichaelKitt-dob	unknown-#MichaelKitt-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	328	I will allow Deputy Pearse Doherty to ask a brief question
column3: as we have gone over time.

column1: #PearseDoherty	unknown-#PearseDoherty-party	unknown-#PearseDoherty-dob	unknown-#PearseDoherty-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	329	Without going into the details of any company
column3: the Minister is well aware that the "double Irish" practice exists. Companies set up secondary Irish companies
column4: register in tax havens
column5: base their intellectual rights there and pay a dividend from the Irish resident company to the tax haven resident company. It is not that they are paying less than 12.5%
column6: but the companies' overall profits are being siphoned off to secondary companies that do not pay tax. They do not do this to avoid paying tax in Ireland
column7: but to avoid paying tax in America
column8: as the interaction between the two companies are not taxed when the profits are repatriated. The Minister
column9: President Obama and the American Administration are well aware of this and we need to be careful so that profitable companies cannot avail of tax loopholes of which the Department is well aware and to which it has turned a blind eye. What contact has the Minister had with the American Administration? Prior to the last presidential election
column10: there was discussion of clamping down on this practice. Changing the American tax code would make attracting American multinationals to Ireland difficult. The Minister needs to tread carefully. While it may be the case that companies are paying tax of 12.5% on the profits registered in Ireland
column11: the Irish tax code allows the "double Irish" practice to exist.

column1: #MichaelNoonan	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-party	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-dob	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	330	My understanding of what Deputy Boyd Barrett describe as the "double Irish" is that while it exists
column3: it cannot be remediated by changes in Irish tax law. Our law applies a rate of 12.5% to the profits of corporations in Ireland. If the situation is to be changed
column4: it is other countries' tax laws that need to be amended
column5: in particular American laws
column6: but it is not within my remit to do so.

column1: #RichardBoydBarrett	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-party	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-dob	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	331	What about raising the effective tax rate?

column1: #MichaelNoonan	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-party	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-dob	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	332	The Deputy is on his own. All of the other parties in the House agree on the 12.5% rate.

column1: #MichaelNoonan	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-party	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-dob	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	333	I am precluded from discussing the tax affairs of any particular individual or company
column3: nor can I discuss the tax administration regimes established in other jurisdictions. However
column4: I advise the Deputy in general terms that a recently published report of the United States Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations of its hearings on offshore profit shifting and the US tax code gave prominence to the tax arrangements of two US multinational corporations
column5: both of which have operations in Ireland. The report finds that US multinational corporations are able to reduce their tax liabilities significantly by legal international tax planning arrangements - there was no allegation of fraud or evasion - and makes recommendations on how US tax law could be improved. Ireland is rightly not mentioned as a tax haven in the report. The international community does not regard Ireland as a tax haven. Ireland has a comprehensive taxation system covering income
column6: capital and indirect taxes. Tax treaties with the United States and many other countries confirm our international standing. The January 2011

column1: global forum peer review report on Ireland's legal and regulatory framework for transparency and exchange of information found that Ireland had an effective system for the exchange of information in tax matters and was fully compliant with OECD standards. Ireland is bound by the same rules on state aid
column2: the code of conduct on business taxation and rulings of the European Court of Justice as all EU member states. Ireland does not support harmful tax competition. Ireland continues to participate fully in the EU code of conduct group
column3: which addresses harmful tax competition
column4: and in the OECD forum on harmful tax practices.

column1: #MickWallace	unknown-#MickWallace-party	unknown-#MickWallace-dob	unknown-#MickWallace-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	334	This is almost the same subject matter as that of the last question. The Minister is probably familiar with research conducted by Mr. Colm Keena. In The Irish Times last week
column3: he showed that Microsoft reduced its US tax bill by more than €1.8 billion in 2011 by using Irish subsidiaries. The company has two branches in this country. Microsoft Ireland Operations Limited
column4: which employs 650 people
column5: showed a profit of $2.2 billion and paid an effective tax rate of 7.3%
column6: amounting to $3.3 million per employee. Microsoft Ireland Research
column7: which has 390 employees in Ireland
column8: had a profit of $4.3 billion on which it paid an effective tax rate of 7.2%
column9: amounting to $11 million per employee. According to Dr. Sheila Killian of Limerick
column10: "[I]t is tempting for multinational firms which have a subsidiary there
column11: and another in a high-tax country to use aggressive transfer pricing practices to shift income into Ireland
column12: where it will face a lower rate of tax". This makes Ireland a tax haven. Problems are coming down the tracks. I do not know whether the Minister has time for bedtime reading
column13: but a new book
column14: entitled The Betrayal of the American Dream
column15: makes for powerful reading. The situation will not stay the same. America is running into serious problems because of its tax laws. The Minister is correct
column16: in that America will need to change its laws to stop significant tax avoidance. He pointed out that much of what is involved is lawful. I will quote from the book-----

column1: #MichaelKitt	unknown-#MichaelKitt-party	unknown-#MichaelKitt-dob	unknown-#MichaelKitt-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	335	No
column3: we cannot allow quotes. I will revert to the Deputy.

column1: #MichaelNoonan	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-party	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-dob	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	336	This is undoubtedly an interesting topic
column3: but both questions are based on a US report on US tax law. It is not a report on Irish tax law. The report notes that there is nothing illegal about this tax planning arrangement and does not identify any failing in Ireland's tax code. This kind of taxation arrangement is run from the US code
column4: not the Irish code
column5: and it is not for us to remediate. We cannot. It is America's tax code that allows for this tax planning. It is a complicated practice
column6: as everyone knows. For example
column7: the transfer pricing rules of America's Internal Revenue Service
column8: IRS
column9: as well as the rules preventing the deferral of US tax and royalty payments and certain other incomes are relevant to non-US subsidiaries of US multinationals undertaking to share the cost of US research and development. This ensures that highly valuable intangible property is partly owned outside the US. Cost saving arrangements in respect of the development of new products typically enable non-US subsidiaries to sell the new products in non-US markets without triggering immediate charges to US tax. US tax on profits of foreign subsidiaries with such arrangements is deferred indefinitely until the profits are repatriated by dividends or otherwise to the US parent company. That is a US arrangement
column10: not an Irish one. Our arrangement is transparent. We have a low corporation tax rate to which Fianna Fáil
column11: Fine Gael
column12: Sinn Féin and the Labour Party subscribe. The 12.5% rate is an incentive to attract inward investment. It works. However
column13: we are not operating a tax haven. No one has ever suggested that we are.

column1: #RichardBoydBarrett	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-party	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-dob	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	337	I suggested it.

column1: #MichaelNoonan	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-party	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-dob	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	338	We are a respectable
column3: tax compliant country with a transparent arrangement. It is a part of public policy to have a low rate.

column1: #MichaelKitt	unknown-#MichaelKitt-party	unknown-#MichaelKitt-dob	unknown-#MichaelKitt-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	339	Deputy Wallace is next
column3: although I nearly called him "Minister".

column1: #MickWallace	unknown-#MickWallace-party	unknown-#MickWallace-dob	unknown-#MickWallace-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	340	The book to which I referred reads: "... the ruling class is defined by its ability to move money beyond the reach of government supervision. This has been accomplished in various ways
column3: but the most important is arguably the establishment of a belief that government has no business in business". We need to change how the world works. The Minister believes that
column4: as with the financial transaction tax
column5: we cannot make a change unless the British do so as well.The manner in which this world operates must and will change because the current process is not sustainable. In 1945
column6: the corporate tax take in America was 7.2% of GDP and it is now 1% of GDP. That country is falling apart so it will change the rules in a process that will have an impact on us. We must start preparing for that now by focusing more on the creation of indigenous industry. We are very reliant on the multinationals which will not stay here forever and we must start working towards the day when we can be a bit more independent of that income. The Americans will change the rules or their country will implode.

column1: #MichaelNoonan	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-party	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-dob	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	341	This issue always arises in the run-in to American presidential elections
column3: with both parties taking up positions on what might be done by them if their candidate is elected. Our embassy in Washington DC and the presence of the IDA in North America monitors these issues very closely and reports back the emerging position. One can take it that people here are aware of the current position
column4: as it is watched very carefully. So far I have not come across any proposals along the line suggested by the Deputy
column5: which would be immediately injurious to Ireland's 12.5% corporation tax rate.

column1: #MickWallace	unknown-#MickWallace-party	unknown-#MickWallace-dob	unknown-#MickWallace-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	342	The Minister should read The Betrayal of the American Dream. It is very good.

column1: #MichaelNoonan	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-party	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-dob	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	343	There are books about everything.

column1: #MichaelKitt	unknown-#MichaelKitt-party	unknown-#MichaelKitt-dob	unknown-#MichaelKitt-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	344	I will allow brief questions from Deputies Doherty
column3: Mathews and Boyd Barrett.

column1: #PearseDoherty	unknown-#PearseDoherty-party	unknown-#PearseDoherty-dob	unknown-#PearseDoherty-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	345	The Minister has indicated that this has nothing to do with Irish tax law and American tax law is involved. Nevertheless
column3: Irish tax law is at the centre of the issue. I indicated I would not mention a company but 1% of Google's sales were recorded in tax in Ireland in 2008. Where did the rest of it go? Some €5.4 billion of its profits were transferred to a Dutch holding company
column4: and Irish tax law means that royalties paid from Google to the holding company in the Netherlands are exempt from tax. That is where Irish tax law fails. Some 98% of the royalties received by the Dutch company go to Bermuda
column5: which is a tax haven. Irish tax law can deal with this by tackling the exemption that operates between Irish and European companies
column6: which is what some of the big multinationals are using. They are transferring profits to other European countries and in turn to tax havens in Bermuda. It is well known and we can do something about it.

column1: #PeterMathews	unknown-#PeterMathews-party	unknown-#PeterMathews-dob	unknown-#PeterMathews-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	346	I raised the question with the Department of Finance of the effect of an increase in corporation tax from 12.5% to 15% in a year. The answer was complicated but the figure given was approaching €700 million. I believe
column3: and I hope the Minister agrees
column4: that we should start considering this. International tax planning is a separate consideration but there is a corporation profit space in this country that must be addressed. Perhaps the rate could run for ten years. I remember when the corporation tax rate was 35% and there was export sales relief for companies with exports. A rate of 15%
column5: if it could raise €700 million
column6: is worthy of consideration and we should look into it.

column1: #RichardBoydBarrett	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-party	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-dob	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	347	I strongly disagree with the Minister. Ireland has become Europe's version of the Cayman Islands. It is part of an international architecture for tax avoidance in multinationals. This system of tax avoidance
column3: of which we form a critical part in Europe
column4: is destabilising the global economy. As multinationals are increasingly not paying tax across the world - an act we facilitate - there is a destabilising effect on the world economy
column5: meaning there is no money available to invest in social goods in the real economy or sustainable industry and enterprise. We cannot just throw up our hands and indicate
column6: as we seem to do with everything
column7: that we are powerless to act on this. We should act because there will be a correction with this issue
column8: as there was with other bubbles
column9: and we should get in ahead of the game. To make low corporate tax rates the cornerstone of industrial policy
column10: as this and previous Governments have done
column11: is to make ourselves a hostage to fortune. Unless we prepare for what will happen
column12: we will live to rue the day. Will the Minister consider the question of at least raising the effective tax rate to 12.5% in an effort to deal with our budgetary crisis?

column1: #MichaelNoonan	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-party	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-dob	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	348	The Government is committed to the 12.5% corporate tax rate.

column1: #RichardBoydBarrett	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-party	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-dob	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	349	What about the effective rate?

column1: #MichaelNoonan	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-party	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-dob	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	350	We will maintain the 12.5% corporate tax rate during the life of this Government. If we come back to government
column3: we will continue to maintain it. I understand the Fianna Fáil
column4: Labour and Sinn Féin parties have a similar position. Some time ago Sinn Féin had a policy document arguing that the corporation tax rate should be increased to 15% but that has been dropped and the party is committed to the 12.5% rate. Last year was a record year for inward investment and this year will be another record. It is a big driver of high-level employment and we will not put that at risk by tinkering with corporation tax.

column1: #RichardBoydBarrett	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-party	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-dob	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-10-04 00:00:00	Address by H.E. Mr. Martin Schulz
column2: President of the European Parliament	351	We are not seeing much of an effect.
